ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This course is challenging but very rewarding. Os is one of the best teachers in the school, in my opinion. He is very fair and honest about the workload at the beginning of the semester. He was willing to work with me anytime I asked for a meeting, and clearly has a passion for what he teaches.
Very heavy amount of work and a very challenging class. Having just finished though, I think this is the most valuable course I've taken at FES in my first year.

This course was truly a terrific component of my education at FES and will be one of the most influential classes in my time here. Os manages to teach conservation in a way that fluidly blends theory and application.

I thoroughly enjoyed this course! I feel like the PVA assignment was not so useful, and it may be better to spend more time on the mapping exercises (assignment 2-4). While I am excited to have these preliminary skills for species distribution modeling, it would be great to be able to understand it well enough to do these types of things in the real world. Right now, it seems that the point of this course is to understand these types of models, but we don't know enough to do it professionally. It just seems like a missed opportunity.

An amazing class. I would recommend to anyone with an interest in conservation. The course seems daunting at first, but with the workshops to teach R and QGIS throughout the course, I managed to emerge with a more robust skill set. I thought I wouldnt survive the course, but I did and enjoyed it the time!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: - the species distribution modeling
Os is an excellent teacher, and this was a very helpful overview of designing management plans for wildlife viability using technical skills.
This class fosters huge personal/academic growth in a very short time period. I loved the learning curve, and feel that I have gained very strong technical skills in this class.

Lectures were extremely interesting and provided a deeper understanding of applied conservation biology. While assignments were incredibly challenging and time consuming, they certainly served their purpose and provided students with hands-on, technical knowledge of tools and programs that are critical work in conservation.
Learning the skills and framework to do comprehensive and science-based conservation planning.
I enjoyed the homework assignments and the group work.

I believe I learned more transferable skills from this course than any other at FES. The assignments give you the chance to practice different spatial and population modeling skills that will be very useful to anyone engaged in landscape-scale conservation work.

The built in class workshops were an essential component. Without them I don't think I could have made as much progress as I did. I also really appreciated that we used R and QGIS which are both open source softwares as I plan to work in the developing world. Having the opportunity to choose our own study areas was also a great aspect of this course because it exposed the students to the difficulties of getting enough data. it also teaches you to be creative in how you fill that gap, always being aware of the assumptions you must make.
Applying the spatial modeling techniques we were learning to real scenarios in the assignments and final project
The course was very valuable for me as a conservationist. It exposed me to spatial analysis adequately and I am glad that I will carry this sort of work forward in my career.

The best aspect of this course is the actual skills you learn in this course. All of these skills and lectures are very applicable to future jobs and can help make students to do better analyses and marketable to the job market.
The material is critical to conservation science.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: - wish the lectures were more advanced, seemed relatively basic. Specifically, I wish we had discussed more of the underlying assumptions in the models instead of simply find/replacing R code, and using them somewhat blindly. - was a little disappointed in the stewardship lectures. I like the intent of discussing stewardship, but think the execution could be improved in two ways: 1) on the lecture portion, could have had more discussion, it was one of the few lectures that ran out of time without any time for questions. I had a couple issues with the underlying assumptions, such as the only options are windmills on tops of mountains or the world is going to end from climate change. It was weird because the whole course, Os does a great job of talking about scenario planning and variants on outcomes, and then when it comes to climate change it's life or death. and 2) on the break-out groups, would be way better if it was a specific example. It was the most vague tee-up of all time, and so you're just not going to get anything useful out of it. Let's talk through a very specific problem!
R. The course should require students to have a previous interaction with the statistical software.

There are several things that would make this course better. First, I think group projects, while valuable, should require equitable group sizes throughout the class. The workload is hugely disparate when there are groups of three and groups of 6 with the same expectations for all. Second, access to Yale computers that have the software required for this class (QGIS and CircuitScape) should be available, because most student's laptop do not have the RAM required to run huge datasets through these applications successfully. Finally, the readings were hugely helpful, but my sense was that most student didn't do them because they were rarely mentioned in class and Os reviewed them in his lectures. If he could create a mechanism for accountability to ensure students do the readings before lectures, the class would get a lot out of it. Folks manage their workload according to what's required, so even though we of course could have held ourselves accountable, it's helpful to have that institutionalized.

This course would benefit from more than one TA, as well as support from Yale computer labs. Some work was too heavy for laptops, and necessary software programs could not always be downloaded onto school desktops.
There should be additional support for students who are new to either R or GIS. The TA was very knowledgeable, but had limited availability across all students in the class.

I wish I had more support / experience with R prior to the course. It was a very steep learning curve early on and I often felt helpless without Matthew's assistance. I think it might be helpful of Os had a better idea of the modeling that was required as this might make prerequisites clearer.

Overall I don't think the course needs much improvement. However, I came into the class with a basic level of skill in R and GIS. Many students did not have any experience with these types of software, and I think they found the course very challenging because of that. While there were some basic workshops set up to help introduce students to the software, I don't think they were extensive enough.
I would have like to have more seminar type classes to discusses problems/challenges with our projects as we progressed and to also discuss some of the topics that Os lectured on.

The software materials (Excel processes, R scripts, GIS procedures, Maxent, Circuitscape) that formed the heart of the project work were in some cases not properly ready for the course, especially true of the R scripts (which needed more documentation as well as testing). There was not nearly enough teaching fellow support. And, while very knowledgeable and more than generous with his time, the one teaching fellow worked better with Apple than with Windows and other products. The time students wasted on incompletely prepared or presented software materials and on struggling with downloading internet materials without more instructions for doing so (these were very complex files to find, select, download and convert) should be considered unconscionable. The workshops were not workshops. They went too rapidly and included too little time eliciting student involvement to be considered workshops. Additionally, the materials needed preloaded for the workshops were available far too late (late night before, morning of). On the other hand... The course is being upgraded, developed, brought in line with cutting-edge and state-of-the-science software tools, so it is to be recognized that this year's course was a one-time experience. The course should-not-have-beens were too many and too hard to take to be considered just part of the process of professional development; but, this was certainly not willful, one doubts that the course will be run this way again, and one does not doubt the best intentions and the expertise of the instructor and the teaching fellow. Students in the future will benefit from the beta-testing of this year's students. Oswald Schmitz is responsive to student needs, sometimes recognizing them before the students do; and the opportunity to learn with him is not to be missed. The course had to move in the direction of more software tools to be a good professional-preparation course. Bottom-line: much more teaching-fellow support, better tested software materials, and better-prepared workshops covering less ground per workshop. The workshops will work if the materials are better pretested, if there is proper lead time to preload software and if they are done either as two-day experiences or with optional follow-up sessions.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Workshops is class were very valuable to complement the theory of what we were learning. However, and since these are totally related with R, I think they would be more valuable if people are familiar with the program.
Workshops were very helpful. The first felt too fast paced, but that was likely due to my own lack of knowledge.
I think more discussion would be interesting. I enjoyed the discussing we had and would like to hear more about the diverse experiences and perspectives my classmates provide on conservation.
Yes! The lectures were very helpful for understanding concepts.
The relationship was seamless and I suggest maintaining the workshop style of teaching.
Excellent!

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: am focused on urban ecology, and don't really care about saving animals, but wanted to understand the underlying assumptions on 'see how the sausage is made' from the conservation science/large scale perspective.
I never expected to be this interested in wildlife conservation - Os helped me see how relevant and important it is to my course of study.
I'm interested in how science is applied to conservation in a holistic perspective. While my work is slightly less wildlife focus this class was a great model for how that can be executed.
As someone interested in the practice of species and land conservation, this class gave me quantitative and spatial tools that will be very useful in my future career.
This course helped me learn spatial modeling skills that I hope to incorporate into my dissertation research.
This course was highly relevant and I highly recommend it for anyone working or looking to work in the conservation field.
As a conservationist, you NEED this course. Do not think twice!
Pivotal. Conservation science is the interest around which I am building my program.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: see above
I took this course because I consider imperative to learn from a science perspective to design and tackle conservation problems from a more holistic and pertinent manner.
Because Os is an excellent teacher and I'd heard great things about the class.

I wanted to strengthen my technical skills, particularly with GIS. I also wanted an introduction to R that was rooted in real world problem solving within the conservation field. This was my third class with Os, which was another strong pull. I very much appreciate his teaching style.
The understanding provided is not replicable through other FES coursework and is valuable to my career goals.
I'm interested in how science is applied to conservation in a holistic perspective. While my work is slightly less wildlife focus this class was a great model for how that can be executed.
Wanted to learn useful skills for my future career.

I plan on working in Conservation in the future and lacked the modeling skills. I also wanted to take a class that would be practical and this was it. Since I will work in areas without the best technology it was great to have exposure to R and QGIS and to learn how to use both packages. The project I worked on could have real implications for how conservation and development are reconciled in my groups study area and this made learning these difficult to master tools more enjoyable.

I took this course to learn techniques that are central to applied conservation science. I hope to be able to use these skills in my own dissertation research and that these skills will make me more marketable when applying to conservation jobs in the future.
Direct link to my area of expertise and interest.
I wanted to learn conservation analysis tools to become a better scientist and conservation biologist.
I am taking as many conservation science courses as I can, and I looked forward to taking courses with Professor Schmitz.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yup
Yes.
Yes - although the process of learning them and using them was a huge challenge.
Yes, and then some. I learned more in this class than I have in any other classes I've ever taken, including during my undergraduate work.
The knowledge I gained, specifically the technical use of R and GIS, exceeded my expectations.
I wasn't sure what to expect but this makes me want to learn more modeling techniques.

The course will help me to understand spatial modeling for conservation programs. Although I wish I had the solid skills to do this at a high-level in the future, I am very glad that I took this course.
Yes

YES! A hundred percent! I didn't think I would be able to do anything of this type of modeling work, but alas, I emerged from the class feeling comfortable and confident with both R and QGIS. I wish more classes at FES had this hands on component with real world applications.
Yes.
The skills learnt in this class went above my expectations.
Yes. I gained a lot and more skills than I thought I could do in one semester.
The knowledge/skills that I gained from the course met and exceeded my expectations.
Yes!
Not yet. I will have to work more with the software materials. The lecture materials were superbly prepared and delivered, and these did not disappoint!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Same feedback as with all group work in FES: 1) people each of different levels of care for the class, so tough to fairly distribute work if somebody is really into it, and others are not (and not being totally into it is fine, it's important to prioritize courses at FES). 2) There's no roles within the group, like a group leader, somebody who's job is the model, somebody who knows Y, etc. FES could do a much better job of providing structure on understanding roles in group work and facilitating this. In the real world, successful teams have individuals who have clearly defined roles and responsibilities.

The course is designed for students to work in groups. The final project has a consulting project format in which collaboration and team work are necessary. The most notorious advantage of this approach is that it simulates real life conditions in which working with people and developing team work skills is imperative.
My group dynamic was hugely challenging - my group was smaller than others in the class and workload felt disproportionate.

There are always pros and cons to group work, and dealing with both provide real world skills. I had a strong group in most ways, though we did struggle with one member who did not produce material at the rate that was needed. This required problem solving and compromise, which I see as a necessary part of the learning process here.

Group members bring varied perspectives and expertise to the term project. However, there is no check on the contributions of each team member. I would recommend a peer evaluation be incorporated into grading for this course, so that individuals are held more accountable for their work.

I was really frustrated by my group work but feel this is more representative of my choice of group members rather than the framework for the group project. I consistently felt as though I were the only member of the group meeting our internal deadlines and completing the work I had committed to completed. I ended up picking up a lot of slack for other team members in the midst of a very heavy semester. This project lends itself well to a team but was a struggle for me.
The group aspect was great. Without my group I dont think I would have learned as much. We did all our assignments together and helped each other troubleshoot. A value addition to the class.

Working in the group for the final project was great because we were able to help each other out and learn from one another, since we had different strengths. Coordinating was a bit difficult in a group of 6, but we planned things well in advance and scheduling ended up worked out well.

The group setting was very good and I highly recommend maintaining it in the coming years. Everyone in the group had the opportunity to show=off their spatial analysis skills, presentation and report writing.
I worked with a really good group of students that brought different strengths to the project.

Group works seems entirely appropriate and beneficial for this course. It has the advantages of expanding the amount of work that could be covered to take a system/ landscape approach. The work is also very conducive to drawing on different team members strengths for the projects. A disadvantage, as with any group work, would be the possibility of ending up in a group that did not have a good work dynamic. However, I was very pleased with my group.
Group work always gets sticky. Nothing new here.
The project needed a group. It was a big project. And the skills on which the project worked were the skills of a professional conservation scientist preparing a report.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If you have never used R before, this course is going to take a lot of your time. And it's going to frustrate the hell out of you. But that's the learning curve for R. You'll be glad you learned it.
Take it if interested in conservation. Very good professor and good methodology approach. However, be aware that it is a 4 credit course and that it is designed to work in R.

Make sure you have enough RAM to run this software. It's VERY helpful to have prior knowledge of statistics and GIS. Each assignment can take up to 20 hours a piece. And make sure the group you join is as large as possible to distribute the workload.

Do not take this course if you're easily discouraged--I once ran through the same R script for nearly 15 hours before I was able to produce anything worthwhile! If you're willing to work, though, this course is exactly what we all need. It's a truly wonderful learning opportunity for those willing to put the time in (and for those who can handle a little bit of stress from time to time)! Os is an incredible teacher, and you will leave this class impressed with all that you've learned.
This course is a very heavy time commitment, but is worth taking. Consider the combination of classes you would be taking with this course, but try to work it into your schedule before leaving FES.
It's a heavy load and helps to have R skills beforehand, but it's worth it.
Start early on assignments and don't be afraid to ask for help from the TA or from Os.
Do it! It's definitely worth the huge amount of work. I learned more in this course than in just about any other at FES.

Just do it! The class sounds scary if you arent comfortable with R or QGIS, but you will learn and you will master them. I came in with little knowledge of both and survived and even thrived. Os and his TA will help you along the way and you will become a modeling master!
Start assignments early and work with others.
If you are in conservation, you MUST take this class***
Prepare to work a lot but it is worth it. There will be lots of frustrating moments and challenges but I think it helps you improve your skills and prepare you for the future.

Try to plan a format and approach for the final report early in the semester. It may be difficult to do this without having worked through all the exercises. You may also be focused on just getting the current assignment done. But the more you can be coordinated with your group members and working toward the final project, the better shape you will be in at the end of the semester.

If you are learning conservation biology, take the course. Seek out assistance as often as you need it, as soon as you need it. Start the assignments as soon as you can, and work on them intensely early on. It is a good course, and the software and support issues of this year should be much less of an issue for you. R, GIS, Maxent and Circuitscape (and programs similar to Circuitscape) are the newest tools in the conservation science toolbox, so let's master them.
